headline: üëÅÔ∏è Monday's Reality Check
quirkyIntro: Happy Monday! While you were drinking your morning coffee, here's what the powers-that-be were up to. Spoiler: it's not great.
tldr: New disability paperwork requirements proposed that make War and Peace look like a pamphlet, plus two municipalities got caught delaying accessibility upgrades they promised 3 years ago. Business as usual!

violations.title: Paperwork Explosion Proposed for Disability Claims
violations.plainEnglish: A new proposal wants injured workers to fill out 47 pages of forms instead of the current 12. Because apparently being injured isn't stressful enough already.
violations.whatItMeans: If this passes, you'll need a full day just to complete the paperwork. Many people might give up - which, suspiciously, seems to be the point.
violations.legalBasis: Potential CHRA Section 5 violation - disability discrimination

violations.title: Accessibility Deadlines? What Deadlines?
violations.plainEnglish: Two major cities missed their AODA deadline for accessible transit stops. Their excuse? 'Supply chain issues.' The deadline was set in 2019.
violations.whatItMeans: People using wheelchairs or mobility aids still can't access 23% of transit stops. That's not a delay - that's neglect.

violations.title: WSIB Appeal Backlog Hits New Record
violations.plainEnglish: The backlog for WSIB appeals is now 18 months. That's a year and a half of injured workers waiting to find out if they'll get help.
violations.whatItMeans: If you file an appeal today, you might get an answer by summer... of 2026. Many people run out of savings while waiting.

violations.title: Denial Rate Up 12% This Quarter
violations.plainEnglish: Initial claim denials jumped 12% compared to last year. More people getting hurt, fewer getting help. Math isn't mathing.
violations.whatItMeans: Your first application has a higher chance of being rejected, meaning more time, stress, and paperwork to fight for what you deserve.

violations.title: Mandatory Medical Assessment Locations Reduced
violations.plainEnglish: They closed 3 medical assessment centers. Now some people have to travel 4+ hours for a mandatory appointment. With an injury. Makes sense, right?
violations.whatItMeans: If you can't make the trip, your claim gets marked 'non-compliant.' They know many people can't travel that far - that's the quiet part.
violations.legalBasis: CHRA duty to accommodate, UNCRPD Article 25

goodNews.title: Community Legal Clinic Wins Big Appeal
goodNews.description: A free legal clinic helped 23 injured workers win their appeals this month. Pro bono lawyers: 23, Bureaucracy: 0.
